metadata.subject: Mathematics
metadata.curriculumSubtopic: Mathematical proof, pattern analysis, logical reasoning, justification strategies

questions.question: Look at this pattern: 3, 6, 9, 12, ___. What comes next and why?
questions.answer: 15, because the pattern adds 3 each time
questions.explanation: Each number increases by 3: 3+3=6, 6+3=9, 9+3=12, so 12+3=15. This is the pattern of multiples of 3.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Pattern 3,6,9,12 next number why? Pattern reasoning: 15, adds 3 each time.

questions.question: True or False: All even numbers are divisible by 2. Explain your reasoning.
questions.answer: True, because that's how even numbers are defined
questions.explanation: Even numbers are defined as numbers that can be divided by 2 with no remainder. So by definition, all even numbers are divisible by 2.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Even numbers divisible by 2 true or false explain? Mathematical definition: True, by definition.

questions.question: If you add any two odd numbers, will the result always be even? Give an example to support your answer.
questions.answer: Yes, always even. Example: 3 + 5 = 8 (even)
questions.explanation: Odd numbers end in 1, 3, 5, 7, or 9. When you add two odd numbers, you get an even number. Examples: 1+3=4, 5+7=12, 9+1=10.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Add two odd numbers always even? Number properties: Yes, example 3+5=8.

questions.question: Explain why 6 × 8 gives the same answer as 8 × 6.
questions.answer: Because multiplication is commutative - the order doesn't matter
questions.explanation: The commutative property of multiplication states that changing the order of factors doesn't change the product. 6×8 = 8×6 = 48.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Why 6×8 same as 8×6? Mathematical properties: Commutative property.

questions.question: Is it possible for a triangle to have two right angles? Explain why or why not.
questions.answer: No, because triangle angles must sum to 180°, and two right angles = 180°
questions.explanation: Two right angles = 90° + 90° = 180°. Since all triangle angles must sum to 180°, there would be 0° left for the third angle, which is impossible.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Triangle two right angles possible? Geometric reasoning: No, angles sum to 180°.

questions.question: Look at this sequence: 1, 4, 9, 16, ___. What pattern do you notice?
questions.answer: 25, these are perfect squares: 1², 2², 3², 4², 5²
questions.explanation: Each number is a perfect square: 1=1², 4=2², 9=3², 16=4², so next is 5²=25.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Sequence 1,4,9,16 pattern? Square patterns: 25, perfect squares 1²,2²,3²,4²,5².

questions.question: If a number is divisible by both 2 and 3, what else must it be divisible by? Explain.
questions.answer: It must be divisible by 6
questions.explanation: If a number is divisible by both 2 and 3, it must be divisible by their product: 2×3=6. This is because 2 and 3 have no common factors other than 1.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Number divisible by 2 and 3, what else? Divisibility reasoning: Must be divisible by 6.

questions.question: Explain why any number multiplied by 0 equals 0.
questions.answer: Because multiplication means adding a number to itself multiple times, and adding nothing (0 times) gives 0
questions.explanation: Multiplication by 0 means you have 0 groups of that number, or you add the number 0 times, which always results in 0.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Why number times 0 equals 0? Zero property: Adding number 0 times gives 0.

questions.question: Which is larger: 3/4 or 2/3? Explain how you know without calculating decimals.
questions.answer: 3/4 is larger. Compare using common denominators: 9/12 vs 8/12
questions.explanation: Using common denominator 12: 3/4 = 9/12 and 2/3 = 8/12. Since 9 > 8, we have 3/4 > 2/3.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: 3/4 or 2/3 larger without decimals? Fraction reasoning: 3/4 larger, 9/12 vs 8/12.

questions.question: If you know that 7 × 8 = 56, how can you quickly find 7 × 16?
questions.explanation: Since 16 = 8 × 2, we can use the fact that 7 × 8 = 56 and multiply by 2 to get 7 × 16 = 112.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Know 7×8=56, find 7×16 quickly? Known facts: 7×16 = 56×2 = 112.

questions.question: Why does the area of a rectangle equal length × width?
questions.answer: Because area counts unit squares, and you have 'width' rows of 'length' squares each
questions.explanation: Area measures how many unit squares fit inside. If you arrange unit squares in a rectangle, you get 'width' rows, each containing 'length' squares, giving width × length total squares.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Why rectangle area = length×width? Area reasoning: Width rows of length squares each.

questions.question: Is 1 a prime number? Explain your reasoning.
questions.answer: No, because prime numbers must have exactly two factors, but 1 only has one factor (itself)
questions.explanation: Prime numbers are defined as having exactly two factors: 1 and themselves. Since 1 only has one factor (itself), it doesn't meet the definition of a prime number.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Is 1 prime number explain? Prime definition: No, needs exactly two factors, 1 has one.

questions.question: Emma claims that if you multiply any three consecutive numbers, the result is always divisible by 6. Test this with examples and explain why this works.
questions.answer: True. Examples: 1×2×3=6, 2×3×4=24, 3×4×5=60. Works because one number is divisible by 2 and one by 3
questions.explanation: Among any three consecutive numbers, at least one is even (divisible by 2) and exactly one is divisible by 3. Since the product contains factors of both 2 and 3, it's divisible by 6.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Three consecutive numbers product divisible by 6? Consecutive properties: True, contains factors 2 and 3.

questions.question: Compare these two methods for finding 25% of 80: Method A: 80 ÷ 4, Method B: 0.25 × 80. Explain why both work.
questions.answer: Both give 20. Method A works because 25% = 1/4, so finding 25% means dividing by 4. Method B converts 25% to decimal 0.25
questions.explanation: 25% = 25/100 = 1/4 = 0.25. Method A uses the fraction form (dividing by 4), Method B uses the decimal form (multiplying by 0.25). Both represent the same mathematical operation.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: 25% of 80: divide by 4 vs multiply 0.25, why both work? Equivalent methods: 25%=1/4=0.25.

questions.question: Jake says 'If a number ends in 0, it's divisible by both 2 and 5.' Is this always true? Prove your answer.
questions.answer: True. Numbers ending in 0 are even (divisible by 2) and are multiples of 10, which contains factor 5
questions.explanation: Numbers ending in 0 are even, so divisible by 2. They're also multiples of 10, and since 10 = 2×5, they contain 5 as a factor and are divisible by 5.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Numbers ending 0 divisible by 2 and 5 always true? Divisibility proof: True, even and multiples of 10.

questions.question: Analyze this pattern: 2, 6, 18, 54, ___. Find the rule and explain why it works.
questions.explanation: Each term is 3 times the previous term. This creates a geometric sequence with first term 2 and common ratio 3.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Pattern 2,6,18,54 rule and why? Geometric analysis: 162, multiply by 3 each time.

questions.question: Maria says 'The sum of any five consecutive numbers is always divisible by 5.' Test this claim and explain the mathematical reason.
questions.answer: True. Example: 3+4+5+6+7=25. Works because sum = 5×(middle number), so always divisible by 5
questions.explanation: Five consecutive numbers can be written as (n-2), (n-1), n, (n+1), (n+2). Their sum is 5n, which is always divisible by 5.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Five consecutive numbers sum divisible by 5? Consecutive proof: True, sum = 5×middle number.

questions.question: Compare the areas of a 4×6 rectangle and a 3×8 rectangle. Without calculating, predict which is larger and explain your reasoning.
questions.answer: They're equal. Both have area 24. 4×6 = 3×8 because 4×6 = 24 and 3×8 = 24
questions.explanation: 4×6 = 24 and 3×8 = 24. Although the shapes are different (4×6 is more square-like, 3×8 is more rectangular), they have the same area.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: 4×6 vs 3×8 rectangle areas which larger? Area comparison: Equal, both area 24.

questions.question: Explain why subtracting a negative number is the same as adding a positive number. Use a number line to support your reasoning.
questions.answer: On a number line, subtracting means moving left, but subtracting a negative reverses direction to moving right, which is adding
questions.explanation: Subtracting normally moves left on the number line. But subtracting a negative number means 'remove a movement to the left,' which becomes a movement to the right (addition).
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Why subtract negative = add positive? Number line reasoning: Reverses direction, left to right.

questions.question: Tom claims that in any group of 7 people, at least 2 must have birthdays in the same month. Is he correct? Explain your reasoning.
questions.answer: No. 12 months, 7 people. It's possible each person has a birthday in a different month (only need 7 of 12 months)
questions.explanation: Since there are 12 months and only 7 people, it's possible for each person to have a birthday in a different month. Tom would be correct if there were 13 or more people.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: 7 people, 2 same birthday month? Pigeonhole reasoning: No, 12 months for 7 people.

questions.question: Show that the sum of two even numbers is always even by using algebraic reasoning.
questions.answer: Even numbers are 2k and 2m. Sum: 2k + 2m = 2(k + m). Since this has factor 2, it's even
questions.explanation: Any even number can be written as 2k for some integer k. Two even numbers are 2k and 2m. Their sum is 2k + 2m = 2(k + m), which has 2 as a factor, making it even.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Sum two even numbers always even algebraic proof? Algebraic reasoning: 2k+2m=2(k+m), has factor 2.

questions.question: A student says '(a + b)² always equals a² + b².' Give a counterexample and explain the correct expansion.
questions.answer: False. Counterexample: (3+2)² = 25 but 3²+2² = 13. Correct: (a+b)² = a² + 2ab + b²
questions.explanation: (3+2)² = 5² = 25, but 3² + 2² = 9 + 4 = 13. The student forgot the middle term 2ab. Correct expansion: (a+b)² = a² + 2ab + b².
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: (a+b)² = a²+b² always? Counterexample: False, (3+2)²=25 ≠ 3²+2²=13, missing 2ab.

questions.question: Prove that if a whole number is divisible by 9, then the sum of its digits is also divisible by 9.
questions.answer: True. Example: 234 is divisible by 9, and 2+3+4=9 is divisible by 9. This works due to place value properties in base 10
questions.explanation: In base 10, each place value (10, 100, 1000, etc.) leaves remainder 1 when divided by 9. So a number has the same remainder as its digit sum when divided by 9.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Number divisible by 9, digit sum divisible by 9? Divisibility proof: True, base 10 place values.

questions.question: Explain why the angles in any triangle always add up to 180°. Use a visual or logical argument.
questions.answer: If you tear off the three corners of any triangle and arrange them in a line, they form a straight line (180°)
questions.explanation: This works because the triangle's angles together span the same amount as a straight line. Alternatively, if you extend one side of a triangle, the exterior angle equals the sum of the two opposite interior angles, leading to the 180° sum.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Triangle angles sum 180° why? Geometric proof: Tear corners, arrange in straight line.

questions.question: Prove that there are infinitely many prime numbers by explaining why the list of primes can never be complete.
questions.answer: If you multiply all known primes and add 1, the result isn't divisible by any known prime, so either it's prime itself or has new prime factors
questions.explanation: Suppose we have a complete list of primes: p₁, p₂, ..., pₙ. Consider N = (p₁ × p₂ × ... × pₙ) + 1. N isn't divisible by any pᵢ (remainder 1), so N is either prime or has prime factors not in our list. Either way, our list wasn't complete.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Infinitely many primes proof? Infinite proof: Multiply all primes, add 1, creates new prime or prime factors.

questions.question: A student claims: 'If you can tile a rectangle with squares, then all the squares must be the same size.' Prove or disprove this statement.
questions.answer: False. Counterexample: A 3×2 rectangle can be tiled with one 2×2 square and two 1×1 squares
questions.explanation: You can tile a 3×2 rectangle using different sized squares: place a 2×2 square in one corner, then fill the remaining 1×2 space with two 1×1 squares. This shows different sizes can work together.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Rectangle tiling squares same size? Tiling analysis: False, 3×2 uses 2×2 and 1×1 squares.

questions.question: Investigate this conjecture: 'Every even number greater than 2 can be written as the sum of two primes.' Test several examples and discuss what you find.
questions.answer: Examples: 4=2+2, 6=3+3, 8=3+5, 10=3+7, 12=5+7. All tested examples work, but this hasn't been proven for all even numbers
questions.explanation: This is Goldbach's Conjecture, one of the most famous unsolved problems in mathematics. While it's been verified for very large numbers by computers, no general proof exists yet.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Even number sum two primes conjecture? Conjecture investigation: Examples work, Goldbach's unproven.

questions.question: Create a logical argument for why √2 cannot be expressed as a fraction of two whole numbers.
questions.answer: If √2 = a/b (simplified), then 2b² = a². This means a² is even, so a is even. Let a=2c, then 2b² = 4c², so b² = 2c², making b even too. But then a/b wasn't simplified - contradiction
questions.explanation: This is proof by contradiction. We assume √2 = a/b in lowest terms, then show this leads to both a and b being even, contradicting the assumption that the fraction was in lowest terms.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: √2 cannot be fraction proof? Irrational proof: Contradiction - both numerator and denominator even.

questions.question: Analyze this pattern: 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13, ___. Explain the rule and prove why each term relates to the golden ratio.
questions.answer: 21. Fibonacci sequence: each term is sum of previous two. Related to golden ratio φ = (1+√5)/2 ≈ 1.618 because ratios approach φ
questions.explanation: This is the Fibonacci sequence where F(n) = F(n-1) + F(n-2). The ratio F(n+1)/F(n) approaches the golden ratio φ as n increases. This happens because the sequence growth rate equals φ.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Pattern 1,1,2,3,5,8,13 and golden ratio? Fibonacci analysis: 21, ratios approach golden ratio φ.

questions.question: Prove that in any group of 6 people, either 3 of them all know each other, or 3 of them are all strangers to each other.
questions.answer: Consider one person A. A either knows or doesn't know each of the other 5 people. By pigeonhole principle, A knows at least 3 or doesn't know at least 3. Case analysis shows the result holds
questions.explanation: This is Ramsey theory. Take person A: among the other 5 people, A knows at least 3 or doesn't know at least 3 (pigeonhole principle). If A knows 3 people {B,C,D}, either they all know each other (giving our group of 3), or two don't know each other - say B,C don't know each other, then {A,B,C} are the required group where not all know each other.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: 6 people, 3 know each other or 3 strangers proof? Ramsey theory: Pigeonhole principle and case analysis.
